title: 100 followers problem!
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be positive numbers each less than 1, with "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" rational and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" , "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" irrational. Select which of the results "},{"type":"text","text":"must be irrational","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":":"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"bulletList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"A:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" The number "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha + \beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"B:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" The infinite sum "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \sum_{i=0}^{\infty} \alpha c^i "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"text","text":"C:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":" The value of the integral "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \int_0^{\pi} \left( \beta \cos(x) + c \right) \,dx "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"heading","attrs":[{"level":3}],"content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thank you, the Brilliant community for the support!"}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \text{(A)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Consider "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha = \sqrt{2}-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta = 2-\sqrt{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", then both "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are irrational but "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha + \beta = 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is rational (note that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0 < \alpha, \beta < 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is also true in this example)."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given one counterexample, statement (A) is definitely not true for all cases."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \text{(B)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"|c| < 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", so we have"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\displaystyle \sum_{i=0}^{\infty} \alpha c^i = \alpha \sum_{i=0}^{\infty} c^i = \alpha \left( \dfrac{1}{1-c} \right) "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now, "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{1}{1-c} \in \mathbb{Q}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\dfrac{1}{1-c} \neq 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for any "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0<c<1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c \in \mathbb{Q}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Therefore, since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is irrational, so "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\alpha \left( \dfrac{1}{1-c} \right) "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be irrational."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \text{(C)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The integration can be solved as"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \int_0^\pi  \left( \beta \cos(x) + c \right) \,dx &= \beta \int_0^\pi \cos(x) \,dx + c \int_0^\pi \,dx \\
&= \beta \left[ \sin(x) \right] {\huge{|}}_{0}^{\pi} + c \left[ x \right] {\huge{|}}_{0}^{\pi} \\
&= c \pi \end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is irrational and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c \in \mathbb{Q}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c \neq 0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", thus "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"c \pi"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" must be irrational."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"horizontalRule"},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Hence options (B) and (C) follow."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

replies.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            Actually, there's a more rigorous proof to show that the sum and/or the difference of two irrational numbers may or may not be an irrational number. However, if either of these two yields a rational result, then the other must yield an irrational result. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The thing is- I have not seen/nor myself proved that there always/not always exists two irrationals within any chosen interval on the real line such that the sum or difference of which yields a rational number. "},{"type":"text","text":"Can you prove it?","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 100 followers problem
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\sum_{x=4}^{11}  \\frac{x^9 + 7x^8 + x^7 -69x^6 -64x^5 + 324x^4 +464x^3 -560x^2 -1212x -320}{x^{10}+4x^9 -12x^8 -64x^7 + 32x^6 + 384x^5 + 128x^4 -1024x^3 - 768x^2 + 1024x +1024}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the value of the above expression to 4 decimal places."}]}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large S =  \displaystyle\sum_{x=4}^{11} \dfrac{x^9 + 7x^8 + x^7 -69x^6 -64x^5 + 324x^4 +464x^3 -560x^2 -1212x -320}{x^{10}+4x^9 -12x^8 -64x^7 + 32x^6 + 384x^5 + 128x^4 -1024x^3 - 768x^2 + 1024x +1024}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":""}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This can be written as "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \displaystyle\sum_{x=4}^{11} \dfrac{x^9 + 6x^8 -64 x^6 - 96x^5 + 192x^4 + 512x^3 - 768x - 512 \\ + ( x^8 -16x^6 + 96x^4 -256x^2 + 256) \\ + ( x^7 + 10x^6 + 36x^5 + 40x^4 - 80x^3 - 288x^2- 380x - 128) \\ + ( x^6 - 4x^5 - 4x^4 + 32x^3 -64x + 64 -16x^2) }{x^{10}+4x^9 -12x^8 -64x^7 + 32x^6 + 384x^5 + 128x^4 -1024x^3 - 768x^2 + 1024x +1024}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"After factorizing:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large S =  \displaystyle\sum_{x=4}^{11} \dfrac{( x+2)^4 ( x-2)^3 (x+2)^2 \\ + (( x+2)^4 ( x-2)^3  (x-2)) \\ +( x+2)^4 (x+2)^2 (x-2)  \\ +( ( x-2)^3 (x+2)^2 (x-2))}{( x+2)^4 ( x-2)^3 (x+2)^2 (x-2)}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"This gives us ."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \large S = \displaystyle\sum_{x=4}^{11} \dfrac{1}{(x+2)^4} + \dfrac{1}{(x-2)^3} + \dfrac{1}{(x+2)^2} + \dfrac{1}{(x-2)} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"On simplifying, we get "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \dfrac{1}{6^4} + \dfrac{1}{2^3} + \dfrac{1}{6^2} + \dfrac{1}{2} \\\cdots \\\cdots \\\cdots \\\cdots "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Therefore "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"S"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is telescopic and on simplification gives the answer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\large \boxed{ \color{#E81990}{\boxed{\color{#3D99F6}{2.1346}}}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: Alphabet Roots
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"If "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\alpha"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\\beta"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are roots of the equation "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^{2}-px+q=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" then "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"(\\alpha+\\beta)x-\\frac{1}{2}(\\alpha^{2}+\\beta^{2})x^{2}+\\frac{1}{3}(\\alpha^{3}+\\beta^{3})x^{3}- \\ldots "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is equal to?"}]}]}

19def isPrime(x):
    """Returns 1 if the number is prime, otherwise 0"""
    if x<2:
        return 0
    if floor(x)!=x:
        return 0
    for i in range(2,x):
        if x%i==0:
            return 0
    return 1
i=1
n=0
a=[]
while(n<1000):
    if isPrime(i):
        a.append(i)
        n+=1
    i+=1
sum(a)


"}],"attrs":[{"text":"def isPrime(x):
    """Returns 1 if the number is prime, otherwise 0"""
    if x<2:
        return 0
    if floor(x)!=x:
        return 0
    for i in range(2,x):
        if x%i==0:
            return 0
    return 1
i=1
n=0
a=[]
while(n<1000):
    if isPrime(i):
        a.append(i)
        n+=1
    i+=1
sum(a)

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Python 2.7:","marks":[{"type":"bold"}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"codeBlock","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 1
 2

17from math import sqrt
def prime(n):
    if n <= 1:
        return False
    for test in xrange(2, int(sqrt(n))+1):
        if n % test == 0:
            return False
    return True
total = 0
count = 0
n = 0
while count < 1000:
    n += 1
    if prime(n):
        total += n
        count += 1
print "Answer:", total


"}],"attrs":[{"text":"from math import sqrt
def prime(n):
    if n <= 1:
        return False
    for test in xrange(2, int(sqrt(n))+1):
        if n % test == 0:
            return False
    return True
total = 0
count = 0
n = 0
while count < 1000:
    n += 1
    if prime(n):
        total += n
        count += 1
print "Answer:", total

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We know  that  the  sum  of cubes of  first n  natural  numbers  is  {n(n+1)/2}^2.
By substituting  the value of n  as 100, we get  the  answer as 25502500."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The sum of the first "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" cubes is the square of the sum of the first "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" positive integers. Therefore the answer is"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left[\dfrac{100}{2}(101)\right]^2="}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\color{#D61F06}\boxed{25502500}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 Followers Problem

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \int \frac {dx}{\sqrt{e^{5x}}\sqrt[4]{(e^{2x}+e^{-2x})^3}} & = - \sqrt[p]{q+e^{-rx}} + C & \small \color{#3D99F6} \text{Differentiate both sides w.r.t. }x \\ \frac 1{\sqrt{e^{5x}}\sqrt[4]{(e^{2x}+e^{-2x})^3}} & = \frac d{dx} \left(- \sqrt[p]{q+e^{-rx}} + C \right) \\ \frac 1{e^{\frac 52x} \left(e^{2x}+e^{-2x}\right)^\frac 34} & = - \frac 1p \left(q+e^{-rx}\right)^{\frac 1p -1}\left(-re^{-rx}\right) \\ \frac 1{e^{4x} \left(1+e^{-4x}\right)^\frac 34} & = \frac r {p e^{rx} \left(q+e^{-rx}\right)^{\frac {p -1}p}} \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Comparing the constants on both sides we get "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"q=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r=4"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\implies p+q+r = 4+1+4 = \boxed{9}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

title: 100 Followers problem!
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"There are 2011 positive numbers with both their sum and the sum of their reciprocals equal to 2012. Let "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be one of these numbers, if the maximum value of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x +\\dfrac{1}{x} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" can be expressed as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" \\frac ab"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for coprime positive integers, submit your answer as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a-b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"."}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let\quad { p }_{ 1 }{ ,p }_{ 2 }....{ p }_{ 2010 }\quad be\quad the\quad 2010\quad numbers\quad distinct\quad from\quad x.\\ Then,\quad { p }_{ 1 }+{ p }_{ 2 }+{ ......+p }_{ 2010 }\quad =\quad 2012-x\\ and\quad \frac { 1 }{ { p }_{ 1 } } +\frac { 1 }{ { p }_{ 2 } } +....+\frac { 1 }{ { p }_{ 2010 } } \quad =\quad 2012-\frac { 1 }{ x } \\ Applying\quad Cauchy-Schwarz\quad /\quad AM-GM\quad Inequality,"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\left( \sum _{ i=1 }^{ 2010 }{ { p }_{ i } }  \right) \left( \sum _{ i=1 }^{ 2010 }{ \frac { 1 }{ { p }_{ i } }  }  \right) =(2012-x)(2012-\frac { 1 }{ x } )\quad \ge \quad { 2010 }^{ 2 }\\ \Longrightarrow \quad { 2012 }^{ 2 }-\quad 2012(x+\frac { 1 }{ x } )+1-{ 2010 }^{ 2 }\quad \ge \quad 0\\ \\ \Longrightarrow \quad (x+\frac { 1 }{ x } )\le \frac { 8045 }{ 2012 } "}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":" 
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus,\quad 8045-2012=\boxed{6033}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            "},{"type":"mention","content":[{"type":"text","text":"@prasun bansal"}],"attrs":[{"profile":"https://brilliant.org/profile/prasun-nhhykv/"}]},{"type":"text","text":" You have taken p + 1/p =2 ,which implies p= 1/p =1.
Now, the first equation yields x=2 , while the second equation yields x=0.5.

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

comments.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            The answer is a maximum of 4."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"adding the two equalities, we get
[sum{i=1,2010} (pi + 1/pi) ] + (x + 1/x) = 4024"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Thus"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"maximize (x + 1/x)  is equivalent to minimize [sum{i=1,2010} (pi + 1/pi) ]"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"since p is positive, min value of p + 1/p  = 2 (when p=1)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"==> min [sum{i=1,2010} (pi + 1/pi) ] = 4020"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"==> max (x+1/x) = 4 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"your solution neglects the fact that the variables p1 to p2010 are common in both the inequalities. Your solution would have been correct if the two series were"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p1 + p2 + .. + p2010 + x  = 2012 "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"&"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"1/q1 + 1/q2 + ...+1/q2010 + 1/x = 2012

                                        "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        
                                            
                                        

                                        

                                        
    

    


                                    "}]}

title: 100 Followers Problem Combinatorics
body: {"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find the smallest integer "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" with the following property: "}]},{"type":"text","text":"\n\n"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Given any real numbers "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{1}, a_{2} ,\\ldots, a_{d}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" such that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a_{1}+a_{2}+\\cdots +a_{d}=100"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" 0 \\le a_{i} \\le 1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"i=1,2,\\ldots,d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" it is possible to partition these numbers into "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"k"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" groups (some of which may be empty) such that the sum of the numbers in each group is at most 1."}]}]}

title: 100 followers problem!
body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The diagonal of the square with side 100 cm can be expressed as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a\times\sqrt b cm"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and b is Square Free."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then X=ab"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let Y be the number of trailing zeroes in 100!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let the roots of the quadratic equation "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{x}^{2} + 100 x + 819"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" be p and q"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Then "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{p}^{2} + {q}^{2} = Z"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Let A be the number of trailing zeroes in (X+Y+Z)!"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Find "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X+Y+Z+A "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]}]}

discussion.body:
{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                
                                
                                
                                    
                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I will just give away the answers....  I encourage you to solve them on your own."}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"orderedList","content":[{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The diagonal of the square can be expressed as "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"100\times\sqrt 2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Hence, X=200"}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The number of trailing zeroes in 100! is 24"}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"The roots are -91 and -9... Therefore, Z= 8362"}]}]},{"type":"listItem","content":[{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"X+Y+Z = 8586. Therefore, the number of trailing zeroes in 8586! is 2143. Hence, A= 2143."}]}]}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Adding them all up, you get 10729. "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Cheers! :)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                    
                                
                            "}]}

I hope its clear now . Thanks! "}]},{"type":"text","text":" "}]}

                                            A faster way to calculate Z :
("},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"p+q)^2 -2pq=100^2 - 2*819 "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":"

{"type":"doc","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                        

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"
                                            

                                            
                                            For trailing zeroes, I used Legendré formula for the greatest power of 5 in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":" n! "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" to find number of trailing zeroes in both cases, Vietà's formula for the algebra problem and Pythagoras theorem for the geometry problem.
